why: Calling .add() on the pattern result (after note()) does not combine patterns as expected — the add pattern is sampled at event times, not merged
good: note("c3!4".add("0 1 2 3")) — call .add() on the mini-notation string inside note()

why: s() and sound() are aliases — the second call overwrites the first
good: Use one or the other: s("bd") or sound("bd")

bad: Using gain/volume envelopes alone for crescendo
why: Crescendo is about orchestration (adding instruments, density, register) not just volume
good: Use mask() or structural patterns (<~!8 pattern!24>) to add/remove layers over time

why: Calling note() after scale() is redundant — scale() already maps to pitch
No string interpolation in mini-notation — patterns are parsed at runtime, not template literals
good: Pass variables as function arguments: s("bd sd").bank(myVar)

why: Mini-notation strings become patterns at parse time — JS string methods don't work on them
good: Write the full pattern directly in the string
